questions.prompt_html:
Which choice corrects the error in subject–verb agreement?

The list of required readings were posted yesterday.

choices.label_html: no change
was
have been
are

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the most concise and clear version.

Because of the fact that the bus was late, we arrived after the show had already started.

choices.label_html: Due to the fact the bus was late, we arrived after the show had already started.
Because the bus was late, we arrived after the show started.
The bus being late was the reason we arrived after the show had already started.
We arrived after the show had already started because of the lateness of the bus.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that uses commas correctly.

After finishing her homework she practiced the piano for an hour.

choices.label_html: After finishing her homework, she practiced the piano for an hour.
After finishing, her homework she practiced the piano for an hour.
After finishing her homework she practiced, the piano for an hour.
After, finishing her homework she practiced the piano for an hour.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the correct pronoun case.

The coach handed the schedule to Maya and me.

choices.label_html: I
myself
me
mine

questions.prompt_html:
Select the clearest and most logical modifier placement.

Walking down the street, the bakery's aroma drew us inside.

choices.label_html: Walking down the street, we were drawn inside by the bakery's aroma.
Walking down the street, the bakery's aroma drew us inside.
The bakery's aroma, walking down the street, drew us inside.
We, walking down the street, inside were drawn by the bakery's aroma.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the correct verb form for the conditional sentence.

If she would have known about the meeting, she would have attended.

choices.label_html: would have knew
had known
would know
knows

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that correctly uses apostrophes.

The musicians cases were stacked behind the stage.

choices.label_html: The musician's cases were stacked behind the stage.
The musicians' cases were stacked behind the stage.
The musicians's cases were stacked behind the stage.
The musicians case's were stacked behind the stage.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the most effective transition.

We reached the cabin before sunset. ___, we started a fire and cooked dinner.

choices.label_html: Nevertheless
Meanwhile
For example
Afterward

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that avoids a comma splice.

The play ended, everyone stood and cheered.

choices.label_html: The play ended; everyone stood and cheered.
The play ended, everyone stood and cheered.
The play ended everyone stood and cheered.
The play ended: everyone stood and cheered?

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct comparison.

Of the two routes, this one is more shorter.

choices.label_html: shorter
the most short
more short
most shorter

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the sentence with correct colon usage.

She brought everything for the trip such as: sunscreen, water, and a hat.

choices.label_html: She brought everything for the trip: sunscreen, water, and a hat.
She brought: sunscreen, water, and a hat, for the trip.
She brought everything: for the trip sunscreen, water, and a hat.
She brought everything for the trip such as: sunscreen, water, and a hat.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the best sentence to combine ideas smoothly.

The lecture ended. The professor answered questions for twenty minutes.

choices.label_html: The lecture ended and, the professor answered questions for twenty minutes.
After the lecture ended, the professor answered questions for twenty minutes.
The lecture ended; for twenty minutes the professor answered questions for twenty minutes.
Ending the lecture, twenty minutes of questions were answered by the professor.

questions.prompt_html:
Identify the correct parallel structure.

The job requires attention to detail, punctuality, and to communicate clearly.

choices.label_html: communicating clearly
to communication clearly
to communicate clearly
clear communication

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct pronoun–antecedent agreement.

Every one of the students turned in their assignment on time.

choices.label_html: their
his or her
its
they

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the sentence that avoids wordiness.

At this point in time, we are currently planning our itinerary.

choices.label_html: We are planning our itinerary now.
At this point in time, we are planning our itinerary.
We are currently planning our itinerary at this time.
Currently, at this point in time, we are planning our itinerary.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct hyphenation.

The director gave a well thought out explanation.

choices.label_html: well thought-out
well-thought-out
well-thought out
wellthought-out

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the faulty comparison.

Her essay is better than any student in the class.

choices.label_html: than any other student's in the class
than any student in the class has
than any student in class
than that of the class

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that corrects a fragment.

Because the team practiced late into the night.

choices.label_html: Because the team practiced late into the night. They were exhausted.
The team practiced late into the night; because they were exhausted.
Because the team practiced late into the night, they were exhausted.
The team practiced late into the night, because they were exhausted.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the correct verb tense for a sequence of events.

By the time we arrived, the concert begins.

choices.label_html: begins
had begun
has begun
was begin

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that uses dashes appropriately for emphasis.

He packed the essentials—maps, snacks, and water—for the hike.

choices.label_html: He packed the essentials—maps, snacks, and water—for the hike.
He packed the essentials—maps, snacks, and water, for the hike—.
He—packed the essentials maps, snacks—and water—for the hike.
He packed—the essentials—maps, snacks, and water—for the hike.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the correct preposition.

We were amazed with the artist's attention to detail.

choices.label_html: with
by
of
for

questions.prompt_html:
Select the clearest sentence free of redundancy.

Each and every participant must register in advance beforehand.

choices.label_html: Every participant must register in advance.
Each and every participant must register in advance beforehand.
All participants must register beforehand in advance.
Each participant must all register in advance.

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the error in pronoun reference.

When Jenna met with her sister, she told her that the appointment was canceled.

choices.label_html: When Jenna met with her sister, she told her that the appointment was canceled.
Jenna told her sister that the appointment was canceled.
Meeting with her sister, Jenna, the appointment was canceled.
The appointment was canceled, Jenna told her sister.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence with correct semicolon usage.

We tried to reach you; but your phone was off.

choices.label_html: We tried to reach you; your phone was off.
We tried to reach you; but, your phone was off.
We tried to reach you; but your phone was off.
We tried to reach you your phone was off;

questions.prompt_html:
Identify the sentence that maintains formal style.

The scientist didn't get the results she wanted, so she was like, "whatever."

choices.label_html: The scientist did not get the results she wanted, so she was like, "whatever."
The scientist did not obtain the desired results and decided to stop caring.
The scientist did not obtain the results she expected, so she decided to revise the experiment.
The scientist didn't get the results she wanted; so she was like "whatever."

questions.prompt_html:
Correct the agreement with a collective noun.

The committee are meeting to discuss its recommendations.

choices.label_html: are
were
is
have been

questions.prompt_html:
Select the clearest, least wordy option.

There are many different kinds of varieties of apples available.

choices.label_html: There are many different kinds of varieties of apples available.
Many different varieties of apples are available.
There are many varieties of apples available.
Many apple kinds of varieties are available.

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the misplaced modifier.

The waiter served the dessert to the guests on small plates with whipped cream.

choices.label_html: The waiter served the guests the dessert with whipped cream on small plates.
The waiter served the dessert with whipped cream to the guests on small plates.
The waiter served the dessert to the guests on small plates with whipped cream.
To the guests on small plates with whipped cream the waiter served the dessert.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct idiom.

The speaker was responsible of organizing the panel.

choices.label_html: responsible of
responsible about

responsible to

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the sentence that correctly uses quotation marks and punctuation.

"Did you finish the draft" asked the editor.

choices.label_html: "Did you finish the draft?" asked the editor.

"Did you finish the draft?", asked the editor.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the best transition for cause and effect.

choices.label_html: however
therefore

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the pronoun shift.

When a person studies late, you should take breaks.

he or she

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct restrictive vs. nonrestrictive clause punctuation.

choices.label_html: The hikers, who were carrying extra water, finished first.
The hikers who were carrying extra water finished first.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose the correct comparative structure with "than."

than us

questions.prompt_html:
Select the clearest sentence that avoids passive when active is better.

The award was given to the youngest researcher by the committee.

choices.label_html: The committee gave the award to the youngest researcher.
The award was given to the youngest researcher by the committee.
The youngest researcher was given the award by the committee.

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the faulty parallelism with correlative conjunctions.

choices.label_html: not only talented but also dedicated
not only talented but also has dedication
not only talent but also dedication

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence without a dangling modifier.

After reading the report, the conclusion was unclear.

choices.label_html: After reading the report, we found the conclusion unclear.

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the run-on sentence.

The festival was crowded it rained for an hour.

choices.label_html: The festival was crowded; it rained for an hour.
The festival was crowded, it rained for an hour.
Being crowded, the festival, it rained for an hour.

questions.prompt_html:

questions.prompt_html:

Fix the shift in verb tense.

We walk to the station and then took the bus.

questions.prompt_html:

fewer

questions.prompt_html:
Simplify the sentence to avoid nominalizations.

choices.label_html: We analyzed the data to decide about expansion.

questions.prompt_html:
Correct the placement of a limiting modifier (only).

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that avoids awkward repetition.

choices.label_html: We will plan a plan for the event.

questions.prompt_html:
Fix the ambiguous pronoun reference.

choices.label_html: Leah was excited when she spoke to Mia about her project.
When Leah spoke to Mia about Mia's project, Leah was excited.
When Leah spoke to Mia about the project, Leah was excited.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the correct punctuation with titles.

questions.prompt_html:
Simplify wordy expressions.

choices.label_html: Because the roads were icy, school was closed.
Due to the fact that the roads were icy, school was closed.
On account of the fact of icy roads, school was closed.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose correct verb form after a singular subject joined by "as well as."

questions.prompt_html:
Avoid informal diction in formal writing.

choices.label_html: kind of

questions.prompt_html:
Select correct comma usage with direct address.

Could you, Maria, pass the salt?
Could, you Maria pass the salt?

questions.prompt_html:
Avoid choppy sentences by appropriate coordination.

The wind howled. The windows rattled. The cat hid.

choices.label_html: The wind howled, the windows rattled, the cat hid.
The wind howled and the windows rattled; the cat hid.
The wind howled, and the windows rattled, and the cat hid.

questions.prompt_html:
Avoid vague demonstratives.

choices.label_html: this
this trend

questions.prompt_html:
Select correct punctuation with conjunction adverbs.

We missed the bus, however we arrived on time.

choices.label_html: We missed the bus; however, we arrived on time.
We missed the bus however, we arrived on time.
We missed the bus, however, we arrived on time.
We missed the bus however we arrived on time.

questions.prompt_html:
Avoid cliché and maintain formal tone.

choices.label_html: The plan worked like a charm, and everyone was super happy.
The plan was effective, and everyone was very pleased.
The plan worked magically, and everyone was super-duper happy.

questions.prompt_html:
Choose precise diction.

The instructions were basically unclear.

choices.label_html: basically
somewhat
unclear
not that clear

questions.prompt_html:
Avoid faulty logic in comparisons.

the neighboring city's

questions.prompt_html:
Simplify to avoid wordiness and maintain clarity.

It is important to note that students should submit their assignments by Friday.

choices.label_html: Students should submit their assignments by Friday.
It is important to note that by Friday students should submit their assignments.
Students should, by Friday, submit their assignments, it is important to note.
Assignments, by Friday, are to be submitted, it is important to note.

questions.prompt_html:
Select the sentence that corrects the misplaced modifier.

She nearly drove her kids to school every day.

choices.label_html: She drove her kids to school nearly every day.
